courses.name: Monuments of Art History

cmCourseInfo.description: Consideration of the stylistic and contextual significance of representative monuments in the history of art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Monuments of Art History

courses.name: The Practice of Art History

cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the intellectual foundations of the discipline and an introduction to working methods in the study of art history.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Practice of Art History

courses.name: Prehistoric Aegean and East Mediterranean Art and Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the Aegean region and the east Mediterranean to 1000BC.
cmCourseInfo.title: Prehistoric Aegean and East Mediterranean Art and Archaeology

courses.name: Early Medieval Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of Western Europe and the Byzantine East from the third until the eleventh century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Medieval Art and Architecture

courses.name: Renaissance Art and Architecture (formerly FAH274H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective survey of the major art centres and types of artistic and architectural production in Italy and northern Europe, from the early fifteenth century to the mid-sixteenth. Themes include the relations--artistic, economic and ideological--between northern and southern Europe during this period, the changing role of art in religious life, the emergence of secular themes, and the legacies left by Renaissance art to modern life and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Renaissance Art and Architecture (formerly FAH274H1)

courses.name: Modernism and anti-Modernism, c. 1750-1900

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the advent and development of art movements including Rococo and Neoclassicism; Romanticism and Revolution, Realism and the advent of Photography, Impressionism; Academic art; Post-Impressionism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modernism and anti-Modernism, c. 1750-1900

courses.name: Architecture: Rituals and Monuments

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of architecture from pre-history to the start of modernism, with attention given to the ways in which architecture shapes human experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Architecture: Rituals and Monuments

courses.name: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the buildings, issues and ideas from Neoclassicism to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

courses.name: Emergence of Greek Civilisation

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates the material culture, art and architecture of the Aegean civilizations from the Neolithic through to the building of the palaces of Crete around 2000BC.
cmCourseInfo.title: Emergence of Greek Civilisation

courses.name: City of Rome

cmCourseInfo.description: The art, architecture and archaeology of the city of Rome to AD476.
cmCourseInfo.title: City of Rome

courses.name: Greek Vase Painting

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a comprehensive exploration of the art of Greek vase painting, covering material from the late Geometric period (8th C. BCE) to the late Classical Period (4th C. BCE). While iconography and narrative will form a major portion of the ceontent, the class will also explore issues surrounding material and technique, the prevalent sympotic (drinking) culture and Greek rituals that provides the cultural framework, dynamics of trade, theories of viewership and semiotics, status of the artist, and other historiographical concerns, including problematic issues surrounding the modern practice of collecting.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Vase Painting

courses.name: Art of the Hellenistic Age (formerly FAH317H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Transformation in the visual arts, paintings, sculpture, and mosaics of the expanding Greek world c. 400BC to c. 100BC; the response to Hellenization from the new artistic centres of Asia Minor and Italy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art of the Hellenistic Age (formerly FAH317H1)

courses.name: Netherlandish Renaissance Art and Culture (formerly FAH307H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Painting, sculpture and architecture of the Netherlands in the sixteenth century with reference to the arts in Italy, France, Germany and Spain. Consideration of Netherlandish art in the context of literature, religion, urban expansion, political and economic developments; and as a system of communication. Particular attention devoted to Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel, the rise of secular art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Netherlandish Renaissance Art and Culture (formerly FAH307H1)

courses.name: Venetian Renaissance Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: Form and meaning, theory and practice of painting and architecture in Venice, ca. 1450-ca. 1600. Social, political and cultural contexts of making and viewing art, including works by Giorgione, Titian, Veronese, Tintoretto and Palladio.
cmCourseInfo.title: Venetian Renaissance Art and Architecture

courses.name: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition (formerly FAH385H1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: September 23, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: The origins and development of the Dada and Surrealist movements in early 20th-century Western art, and their lasting impact on art after World War II. Painting, sculpture, graphic arts, and the theoretical preoccupation which accompanied artistic production.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition (formerly FAH385H1)

courses.name: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition (formerly FAH385H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The origins and development of the Dada and Surrealist movements in early 20th-century Western art, and their lasting impact on art after World War II. Painting, sculpture, graphic arts, and the theoretical preoccupation which accompanied artistic production.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition (formerly FAH385H1)

courses.name: Minimalism (formerly FAH389H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the different definitions and issues of minimal art including seriality, materials, process, objecthood, chance, installation, reception, relations to music and film, and the influence of structuralism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Minimalism (formerly FAH389H1)

courses.name: On Display: Cultures of Exhibition, 1789-1900

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of the historical development of the cultures of exhibition in Nineteenth-Century Europe, and the diversity of venues displaying works of art and nature. Historical and theoretical overview is complemented by case studies which include investigations of private cabinets of curiosity, encyclopedic museums, commercial galleries, side-shows, and world's fairs.
cmCourseInfo.title: On Display: Cultures of Exhibition, 1789-1900
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: some introduction to art and/or cultural history

courses.name: World of the Senses: Chinese Decorative Arts

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys late imperial Chinese decorative arts from the Song (960-1127) through Qing (1644-1911) dynasties. It focuses on ceramics/porcelain, textiles, and furniture, attending especially to works in Toronto collections. Students will read primary and secondary sources to learn how decorative arts shaped daily life in imperial China.
cmCourseInfo.title: World of the Senses: Chinese Decorative Arts
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 200-level FAH half course/any 100- or 200-level EAS Society-Culture course.

courses.name: Special Topics in Art History (formerly FAH395H1)

cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Art History (formerly FAH395H1)

courses.name: Problems in Jewish Art (formerly FAH329H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates the changing definition of Jewish art and the status of Jewish artists. Other issues explored include Jewish-Christian visual polemics, the construction of individual and communal Jewish identity through art, architecture, and texts, and the conceptual transformation of Jewish craft and ritual objects into art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Problems in Jewish Art (formerly FAH329H1)
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: FAH102H1, a 200 level FAH half course

courses.name: Cross-Cultural Issues in Ancient Art Beyond Greece and Rome

cmCourseInfo.description: When cultures collide, they assimilate, they exchange, they transform, and they develop, and there seems to be a pattern of recognizable centres of power around which artistic tradition often revolves. This has caused the conventional understanding of certain flowering of artistic heritage as a product of cross-cultural influences. This course is a seminar style survey that explores these fascinating amalgams of artistic traditions that lie at the Eastern outskirts of the Hellenistic world throughout the roman Period, from Bactria to India, and with a heavy focus on the Buddhist art of Gandhara, reaching out along the Silk Road.  As the title suggests, the class aims at a renewed framework that re-evaluates the role of the Ancient West, which has been absent since the heavily Eurocentric scholarship from the early 20th century. It also aims to familiarize students with current theoretical issues surrounding cross-cultural studies as it pertains to the visual arts, touching upon modern postcolonial theories of space.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cross-Cultural Issues in Ancient Art Beyond Greece and Rome

courses.name: Studies in Medieval Cities

cmCourseInfo.description: A focused examination of urbanism, art and architecture of a specific medieval city, such as Jerusalem, Rome, Constantinople, or Paris.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Medieval Cities

courses.name: Dutch Genre Painting of the 17th Century

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Jan 11, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of so-called “scenes of everyday life.” Special attention given to cultural context and problems of interpretation, the work of Jan Vermeer, and the reputation of this art in following centuries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dutch Genre Painting of the 17th Century
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Reading knowledge of French or German

courses.name: 19th-Century Landscape Painting

cmCourseInfo.description: Investigation of English, French, German and Swiss landscape painting from the birth of the Romantic movement to Post-Impressionism.
cmCourseInfo.title: 19th-Century Landscape Painting
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Reading knowledge of French or German

courses.name: Issues in Canadian Art, ca. 1900-1940 (formerly FAH415H1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: September 13, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused, thematic examinations of the visual arts in Canada in the first half of the twentieth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Canadian Art, ca. 1900-1940 (formerly FAH415H1)

courses.name: East Asian Art as a Cultural System

cmCourseInfo.description: Methodologically-focused seminar engaged with recovering and articulating in Western terms indigenous ways of seeing and thinking about East Asian art.
cmCourseInfo.title: East Asian Art as a Cultural System

courses.name: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol in this course, please contact contact Louise Kermode at the Art Department for details, email undergrad.arthistory@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. courses.name: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture (formerly FAH453H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to conservation, designed to give students a basic understanding of the field, its techniques, and its purposes. Sessions conducted by specialists in the Royal Ontario Museum conservation department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture (formerly FAH453H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor.

courses.name: Fashion, & Textiles: Culture & Consumption (formerly FAH459H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the history, meaning and consumption of Western European textiles (Late Antique - 18th century) and fashionable dress (18th - 21st centuries). Analysis and research will combine student seminars with the study of actual artefacts in the Textile & Costume Collection of the Royal Ontario Museum.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fashion, & Textiles: Culture & Consumption (formerly FAH459H1)

courses.name: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum (formerly FAH456H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical and practical engagement with the ROM's Canadian paintings, prints and drawing collections (18th-20th C). Through lectures, workshops, and seminars, we consider the collecting, interpretation, and display of images within the framework of “documentary art” and its various connotations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum (formerly FAH456H1)

courses.name: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth investigation of objects at the Royal Ontario Museum. Content will vary according to the museum department offering the course in any given semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

courses.name: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused examination of special topics in any period of Mediterranean, European, North American, or Asian art and architecture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor

courses.name: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused examination of special topics in any period of Mediterranean, European, North American, or Asian art and architecture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor

courses.name: Introduction to the Textile Arts of the Indian Ocean World

cmCourseInfo.description: The Indian Ocean has been called the Cradle of Globalization. For thousands of years monsoon winds linked the people and arts of this vast Ocean that stretches from East Africa in the West to Indonesia (and beyond) in the East. Throughout its long history, handwoven textiles have been amongst the area’s greatest art forms, trade goods, religious objects and markers of identity. This course will survey the wide variety of these forms, from c. 1100 to 1950. Special attention is placed on India, which lies at the center of the region, and originated many of the fibres, techniques, design and iconography of the wider area. Select regional manifestations are then examined in depth, using the ROM’s extensive collections. These range from the silks of Madagascar, to embroidered men’s wear of Oman, to the cosmopolitan batiks of northern coastal Java. It is seen that all these traditions can best be understood within the framework of the wider Indian Ocean region.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Textile Arts of the Indian Ocean World
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Asian art, Islamic art, or anthropology
